Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since 2000, the annual number of people
convicted of crimes in the United States has stayed steady, but the average number
of people in jail each year has shot up. How can that be? The answer lies in the bail system— which isn’t doing 
what it was intended to do. The term "bail" refers to the release
of people awaiting trial on condition that they return 
to court to face charges. Countries around the world 
use many variations of bail, and some don’t use it at all. The U.S. bail system relies primarily 
on what’s called cash bail, which was supposed to work like this: When a person was accused of a crime, the judge would set 
a reasonable price for bail. The accused would pay this fee 
in order to be released from jail until the court reached 
a verdict on the case. Once the case ended, 
whether found guilty or innocent, they’d get the bail money back 
if they made all their court appearances. The rationale behind this system 
is that under U.S. law, people are presumed innocent
until proven guilty— so someone accused of a crime 
should not be imprisoned unless they’ve been convicted of a crime. But today, the bail system in the U.S. doesn’t honor the presumption
of innocence. Instead, it subverts peoples’ rights
and causes serious harm, particularly to people 
in low-income communities and communities of color. A key reason why is the cost of bail. In order for cash bail 
to work as intended, the price has to be affordable
for the accused. The cost of bail wasn’t meant to reflect
the likelihood of someone’s guilt— when bail is set, the court 
has not reviewed evidence. Under exceptional circumstances, 
such as charges of very serious crimes, judges could deny bail 
and jail the accused before their trial. Judges were supposed to exercise 
this power very rarely, and could come under scrutiny
for using it too often. Setting unaffordably high bail 
became a second path to denying people pretrial release. Judges' personal discretion 
and prejudices played a huge role in who they chose to detain this way. Bail amounts climbed higher and higher, 
and more and more defendants couldn’t pay— so they stayed in jail. By the late 19th century, these circumstances led to the rise 
of commercial bail bond companies. They pay a defendant’s bail, in exchange
for a hefty fee the company keeps. Today, the median bail is $10,000— a prohibitively high price 
for almost half of Americans, and as many as nine out of ten defendants. If the defendant can’t pay, they may apply for a loan 
from a commercial bail bond company. It’s completely up to the company 
to decide whose bail they’ll pay. They choose defendants they think 
will pay them back, turning a profit of about
$2 billion each year. In fact, in the past 20 years, pretrial detention has been the main
driver of jail growth in America. Every year, hundreds of thousands 
of people who can’t afford bail or secure a loan
stay in jail until their case is resolved. This injustice disproportionately affects
Americans who are Black and Latino, for whom judges often set higher bail than for white people accused
of the same offenses. Unaffordable bail puts even innocent
defendants in an impossible position. Some end up pleading guilty to crimes 
they did not commit. For minor offenses, the prosecution 
may offer a deal that credits time already spent in jail toward 
the accused’s sentence if they plead guilty. Often, the time they’ve already spent in
jail is the total length of the sentence, and they can go home immediately—
but they leave with a criminal record. Defending their innocence, meanwhile, can mean staying in jail indefinitely
awaiting trial— and doesn’t guarantee 
an innocent verdict. Bail may not even be necessary
in the first place. Washington, D.C. largely abolished
cash bail in the 1990s. In 2017, the city released 94% 
of defendants without holding bail money, and 88% of them returned
to all their court dates. The nonprofit organization, 
The Bail Project, provides free bail assistance to thousands
of low-income people every year, removing the financial incentive
that bail is designed to create. The result? People come back 
to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, and those who miss their court dates 
tended to because of circumstances like child care,
work conflicts, or medical crises. Studies have also found that holding
people in jail before trial, often because they cannot
afford cash bail, actually increases the likelihood
of rearrests and reoffending. The damage of incarcerating people 
before their trials extends to entire communities
and can harm families for generations. People who are incarcerated 
can lose their livelihoods, homes, and access to essential services— all before they’ve been convicted 
of a crime. It’s also incredibly expensive: American taxpayers spend 
nearly $14 billion every year incarcerating people 
who are legally presumed innocent. This undermines the promise 
of equal justice under the law, regardless of race or wealth. The issues surrounding cash bail 
are symptomatic of societal problems, like structural racism and over-reliance
on incarceration, that need to be addressed. In the meantime, 
reformers like The Bail Project are working to help people trapped 
by cash bail and to create a more just and humane
pretrial system for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When is cash bail set during the legal process?
Options: A. As an alternative to serving a sentence, after you’ve been convicted of a crime., B. As a way to get out if you are in prison., C. After you’ve a been accused of a crime, but before you’ve had your day in court., D. After you decide not to plead guilty.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary intention of the bail system in the United States? Options: A. To punish people accused of crimes, B. To release people awaiting trial on condition that they return to court to face charges, C. To keep people in jail until they are proven guilty, D. To fine people accused of crimes Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main reason why the bail system in the U.S. is not working as intended? Options: A. Judges are not setting high enough bail amounts, B. The cost of bail is not affordable for many people, C. The bail system is not being used often enough, D. The bail system is too lenient on people accused of crimes Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the median bail amount in the United States? Options: A. $1,000, B. $5,000, C. $10,000, D. $20,000 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the result of unaffordable bail for many defendants? Options: A. They are able to pay the bail and go home, B. They are able to secure a loan from a commercial bail bond company, C. They stay in jail until their case is resolved, D. They are able to plead guilty to a lesser charge Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which group of people is disproportionately affected by unaffordable bail? Options: A. White people, B. Black and Latino people, C. Low-income people, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the consequence of staying in jail indefinitely while awaiting trial? Options: A. The defendant is guaranteed an innocent verdict, B. The defendant may lose their livelihood, home, and access to essential services, C. The defendant is able to plead guilty to a lesser charge, D. The defendant is able to go home immediately Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the result of holding people in jail before trial? Options: A. It decreases the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, B. It increases the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, C. It has no effect on the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, D. It depends on the individual case Correct Option: None
Question 8: How much do American taxpayers spend every year incarcerating people who are legally presumed innocent? Options: A. $1 billion, B. $5 billion, C. $10 billion, D. $14 billion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the goal of organizations like The Bail Project? Options: A. To abolish the bail system entirely, B. To provide free bail assistance to low-income people, C. To increase the median bail amount, D. To decrease the number of people released on bail Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the result of The Bail Project's efforts? Options: A. People are more likely to miss their court dates, B. People are less likely to come back to court, C. People come back to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, D. The bail system is abolished entirely Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, based on the topic of bail and the legal process, I would say that Question 4: "What is the result of unaffordable bail for many defendants?" is the closest match.

However, a more suitable match can be created by rephrasing some of the generated MCQs. For example, rephrasing Question 2 to ask "At what point in the legal process is bail typically set?" could make it a closer match.

But if I had to choose from the existing generated MCQs, I would say that none of them match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since 2000, the annual number of people
convicted of crimes in the United States has stayed steady, but the average number
of people in jail each year has shot up. How can that be? The answer lies in the bail system— which isn’t doing 
what it was intended to do. The term "bail" refers to the release
of people awaiting trial on condition that they return 
to court to face charges. Countries around the world 
use many variations of bail, and some don’t use it at all. The U.S. bail system relies primarily 
on what’s called cash bail, which was supposed to work like this: When a person was accused of a crime, the judge would set 
a reasonable price for bail. The accused would pay this fee 
in order to be released from jail until the court reached 
a verdict on the case. Once the case ended, 
whether found guilty or innocent, they’d get the bail money back 
if they made all their court appearances. The rationale behind this system 
is that under U.S. law, people are presumed innocent
until proven guilty— so someone accused of a crime 
should not be imprisoned unless they’ve been convicted of a crime. But today, the bail system in the U.S. doesn’t honor the presumption
of innocence. Instead, it subverts peoples’ rights
and causes serious harm, particularly to people 
in low-income communities and communities of color. A key reason why is the cost of bail. In order for cash bail 
to work as intended, the price has to be affordable
for the accused. The cost of bail wasn’t meant to reflect
the likelihood of someone’s guilt— when bail is set, the court 
has not reviewed evidence. Under exceptional circumstances, 
such as charges of very serious crimes, judges could deny bail 
and jail the accused before their trial. Judges were supposed to exercise 
this power very rarely, and could come under scrutiny
for using it too often. Setting unaffordably high bail 
became a second path to denying people pretrial release. Judges' personal discretion 
and prejudices played a huge role in who they chose to detain this way. Bail amounts climbed higher and higher, 
and more and more defendants couldn’t pay— so they stayed in jail. By the late 19th century, these circumstances led to the rise 
of commercial bail bond companies. They pay a defendant’s bail, in exchange
for a hefty fee the company keeps. Today, the median bail is $10,000— a prohibitively high price 
for almost half of Americans, and as many as nine out of ten defendants. If the defendant can’t pay, they may apply for a loan 
from a commercial bail bond company. It’s completely up to the company 
to decide whose bail they’ll pay. They choose defendants they think 
will pay them back, turning a profit of about
$2 billion each year. In fact, in the past 20 years, pretrial detention has been the main
driver of jail growth in America. Every year, hundreds of thousands 
of people who can’t afford bail or secure a loan
stay in jail until their case is resolved. This injustice disproportionately affects
Americans who are Black and Latino, for whom judges often set higher bail than for white people accused
of the same offenses. Unaffordable bail puts even innocent
defendants in an impossible position. Some end up pleading guilty to crimes 
they did not commit. For minor offenses, the prosecution 
may offer a deal that credits time already spent in jail toward 
the accused’s sentence if they plead guilty. Often, the time they’ve already spent in
jail is the total length of the sentence, and they can go home immediately—
but they leave with a criminal record. Defending their innocence, meanwhile, can mean staying in jail indefinitely
awaiting trial— and doesn’t guarantee 
an innocent verdict. Bail may not even be necessary
in the first place. Washington, D.C. largely abolished
cash bail in the 1990s. In 2017, the city released 94% 
of defendants without holding bail money, and 88% of them returned
to all their court dates. The nonprofit organization, 
The Bail Project, provides free bail assistance to thousands
of low-income people every year, removing the financial incentive
that bail is designed to create. The result? People come back 
to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, and those who miss their court dates 
tended to because of circumstances like child care,
work conflicts, or medical crises. Studies have also found that holding
people in jail before trial, often because they cannot
afford cash bail, actually increases the likelihood
of rearrests and reoffending. The damage of incarcerating people 
before their trials extends to entire communities
and can harm families for generations. People who are incarcerated 
can lose their livelihoods, homes, and access to essential services— all before they’ve been convicted 
of a crime. It’s also incredibly expensive: American taxpayers spend 
nearly $14 billion every year incarcerating people 
who are legally presumed innocent. This undermines the promise 
of equal justice under the law, regardless of race or wealth. The issues surrounding cash bail 
are symptomatic of societal problems, like structural racism and over-reliance
on incarceration, that need to be addressed. In the meantime, 
reformers like The Bail Project are working to help people trapped 
by cash bail and to create a more just and humane
pretrial system for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the purpose of cash bail as originally intended?
Options: A. To punish you financially for committing a crime., B. To create an incentive to return to court until a judge decides the case., C. To pay the court back for the legal fees associated with prosecuting a case., D. To raise funds for police departments.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary intention of the bail system in the United States? Options: A. To punish people accused of crimes, B. To release people awaiting trial on condition that they return to court to face charges, C. To keep people in jail until they are proven guilty, D. To fine people accused of crimes Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main reason why the bail system in the U.S. is not working as intended? Options: A. Judges are not setting high enough bail amounts, B. The cost of bail is not affordable for many people, C. The bail system is not being used often enough, D. The bail system is too lenient on people accused of crimes Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the median bail amount in the United States? Options: A. $1,000, B. $5,000, C. $10,000, D. $20,000 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the result of unaffordable bail for many defendants? Options: A. They are able to pay the bail and go home, B. They are able to secure a loan from a commercial bail bond company, C. They stay in jail until their case is resolved, D. They are able to plead guilty to a lesser charge Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which group of people is disproportionately affected by unaffordable bail? Options: A. White people, B. Black and Latino people, C. Low-income people, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the consequence of staying in jail indefinitely while awaiting trial? Options: A. The defendant is guaranteed an innocent verdict, B. The defendant may lose their livelihood, home, and access to essential services, C. The defendant is able to plead guilty to a lesser charge, D. The defendant is able to go home immediately Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the result of holding people in jail before trial? Options: A. It decreases the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, B. It increases the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, C. It has no effect on the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, D. It depends on the individual case Correct Option: None
Question 8: How much do American taxpayers spend every year incarcerating people who are legally presumed innocent? Options: A. $1 billion, B. $5 billion, C. $10 billion, D. $14 billion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the goal of organizations like The Bail Project? Options: A. To abolish the bail system entirely, B. To provide free bail assistance to low-income people, C. To increase the median bail amount, D. To decrease the number of people released on bail Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the result of The Bail Project's efforts? Options: A. People are more likely to miss their court dates, B. People are less likely to come back to court, C. People come back to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, D. The bail system is abolished entirely Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the options do not exactly match, the question content and intent are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks about the purpose of cash bail as originally intended, while Question 1 asks about the primary intention of the bail system in the United States. Both questions aim to understand the intended function of the bail system.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of options and content. But among the available options, Question 1 is the closest match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since 2000, the annual number of people
convicted of crimes in the United States has stayed steady, but the average number
of people in jail each year has shot up. How can that be? The answer lies in the bail system— which isn’t doing 
what it was intended to do. The term "bail" refers to the release
of people awaiting trial on condition that they return 
to court to face charges. Countries around the world 
use many variations of bail, and some don’t use it at all. The U.S. bail system relies primarily 
on what’s called cash bail, which was supposed to work like this: When a person was accused of a crime, the judge would set 
a reasonable price for bail. The accused would pay this fee 
in order to be released from jail until the court reached 
a verdict on the case. Once the case ended, 
whether found guilty or innocent, they’d get the bail money back 
if they made all their court appearances. The rationale behind this system 
is that under U.S. law, people are presumed innocent
until proven guilty— so someone accused of a crime 
should not be imprisoned unless they’ve been convicted of a crime. But today, the bail system in the U.S. doesn’t honor the presumption
of innocence. Instead, it subverts peoples’ rights
and causes serious harm, particularly to people 
in low-income communities and communities of color. A key reason why is the cost of bail. In order for cash bail 
to work as intended, the price has to be affordable
for the accused. The cost of bail wasn’t meant to reflect
the likelihood of someone’s guilt— when bail is set, the court 
has not reviewed evidence. Under exceptional circumstances, 
such as charges of very serious crimes, judges could deny bail 
and jail the accused before their trial. Judges were supposed to exercise 
this power very rarely, and could come under scrutiny
for using it too often. Setting unaffordably high bail 
became a second path to denying people pretrial release. Judges' personal discretion 
and prejudices played a huge role in who they chose to detain this way. Bail amounts climbed higher and higher, 
and more and more defendants couldn’t pay— so they stayed in jail. By the late 19th century, these circumstances led to the rise 
of commercial bail bond companies. They pay a defendant’s bail, in exchange
for a hefty fee the company keeps. Today, the median bail is $10,000— a prohibitively high price 
for almost half of Americans, and as many as nine out of ten defendants. If the defendant can’t pay, they may apply for a loan 
from a commercial bail bond company. It’s completely up to the company 
to decide whose bail they’ll pay. They choose defendants they think 
will pay them back, turning a profit of about
$2 billion each year. In fact, in the past 20 years, pretrial detention has been the main
driver of jail growth in America. Every year, hundreds of thousands 
of people who can’t afford bail or secure a loan
stay in jail until their case is resolved. This injustice disproportionately affects
Americans who are Black and Latino, for whom judges often set higher bail than for white people accused
of the same offenses. Unaffordable bail puts even innocent
defendants in an impossible position. Some end up pleading guilty to crimes 
they did not commit. For minor offenses, the prosecution 
may offer a deal that credits time already spent in jail toward 
the accused’s sentence if they plead guilty. Often, the time they’ve already spent in
jail is the total length of the sentence, and they can go home immediately—
but they leave with a criminal record. Defending their innocence, meanwhile, can mean staying in jail indefinitely
awaiting trial— and doesn’t guarantee 
an innocent verdict. Bail may not even be necessary
in the first place. Washington, D.C. largely abolished
cash bail in the 1990s. In 2017, the city released 94% 
of defendants without holding bail money, and 88% of them returned
to all their court dates. The nonprofit organization, 
The Bail Project, provides free bail assistance to thousands
of low-income people every year, removing the financial incentive
that bail is designed to create. The result? People come back 
to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, and those who miss their court dates 
tended to because of circumstances like child care,
work conflicts, or medical crises. Studies have also found that holding
people in jail before trial, often because they cannot
afford cash bail, actually increases the likelihood
of rearrests and reoffending. The damage of incarcerating people 
before their trials extends to entire communities
and can harm families for generations. People who are incarcerated 
can lose their livelihoods, homes, and access to essential services— all before they’ve been convicted 
of a crime. It’s also incredibly expensive: American taxpayers spend 
nearly $14 billion every year incarcerating people 
who are legally presumed innocent. This undermines the promise 
of equal justice under the law, regardless of race or wealth. The issues surrounding cash bail 
are symptomatic of societal problems, like structural racism and over-reliance
on incarceration, that need to be addressed. In the meantime, 
reformers like The Bail Project are working to help people trapped 
by cash bail and to create a more just and humane
pretrial system for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When do you get cash bail back?
Options: A. At the end of your case, whether you are found guilty or innocent, so long as you came back for your court dates., B. At the end of your case, but only if you are found innocent., C. You don’t get it back. It is the penalty for getting arrested., D. You don’t get it back. It is the fee for the court to arbitrate a dispute.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary intention of the bail system in the United States? Options: A. To punish people accused of crimes, B. To release people awaiting trial on condition that they return to court to face charges, C. To keep people in jail until they are proven guilty, D. To fine people accused of crimes Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the main reason why the bail system in the U.S. is not working as intended? Options: A. Judges are not setting high enough bail amounts, B. The cost of bail is not affordable for many people, C. The bail system is not being used often enough, D. The bail system is too lenient on people accused of crimes Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the median bail amount in the United States? Options: A. $1,000, B. $5,000, C. $10,000, D. $20,000 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the result of unaffordable bail for many defendants? Options: A. They are able to pay the bail and go home, B. They are able to secure a loan from a commercial bail bond company, C. They stay in jail until their case is resolved, D. They are able to plead guilty to a lesser charge Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which group of people is disproportionately affected by unaffordable bail? Options: A. White people, B. Black and Latino people, C. Low-income people, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the consequence of staying in jail indefinitely while awaiting trial? Options: A. The defendant is guaranteed an innocent verdict, B. The defendant may lose their livelihood, home, and access to essential services, C. The defendant is able to plead guilty to a lesser charge, D. The defendant is able to go home immediately Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the result of holding people in jail before trial? Options: A. It decreases the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, B. It increases the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, C. It has no effect on the likelihood of rearrests and reoffending, D. It depends on the individual case Correct Option: None
Question 8: How much do American taxpayers spend every year incarcerating people who are legally presumed innocent? Options: A. $1 billion, B. $5 billion, C. $10 billion, D. $14 billion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the goal of organizations like The Bail Project? Options: A. To abolish the bail system entirely, B. To provide free bail assistance to low-income people, C. To increase the median bail amount, D. To decrease the number of people released on bail Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the result of The Bail Project's efforts? Options: A. People are more likely to miss their court dates, B. People are less likely to come back to court, C. People come back to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, D. The bail system is abolished entirely Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can try to find the one that is closest in terms of relevance to the bail system and its functionality.

The ground truth MCQ asks about when you get cash bail back. The closest generated MCQ in terms of relevance to the bail system is Question 2, but it does not match the ground truth MCQ's intent.

However, I can suggest that Question 4 is the closest in terms of discussing the consequences of bail, but it still does not directly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose one, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ, but if I had to pick the closest one in terms of relevance to the bail system, I would say Question 4. However, I would like to emphasize that it's not a direct match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since 2000, the annual number of people
convicted of crimes in the United States has stayed steady, but the average number
of people in jail each year has shot up. How can that be? The answer lies in the bail system— which isn’t doing 
what it was intended to do. The term "bail" refers to the release
of people awaiting trial on condition that they return 
to court to face charges. Countries around the world 
use many variations of bail, and some don’t use it at all. The U.S. bail system relies primarily 
on what’s called cash bail, which was supposed to work like this: When a person was accused of a crime, the judge would set 
a reasonable price for bail. The accused would pay this fee 
in order to be released from jail until the court reached 
a verdict on the case. Once the case ended, 
whether found guilty or innocent, they’d get the bail money back 
if they made all their court appearances. The rationale behind this system 
is that under U.S. law, people are presumed innocent
until proven guilty— so someone accused of a crime 
should not be imprisoned unless they’ve been convicted of a crime. But today, the bail system in the U.S. doesn’t honor the presumption
of innocence. Instead, it subverts peoples’ rights
and causes serious harm, particularly to people 
in low-income communities and communities of color. A key reason why is the cost of bail. In order for cash bail 
to work as intended, the price has to be affordable
for the accused. The cost of bail wasn’t meant to reflect
the likelihood of someone’s guilt— when bail is set, the court 
has not reviewed evidence. Under exceptional circumstances, 
such as charges of very serious crimes, judges could deny bail 
and jail the accused before their trial. Judges were supposed to exercise 
this power very rarely, and could come under scrutiny
for using it too often. Setting unaffordably high bail 
became a second path to denying people pretrial release. Judges' personal discretion 
and prejudices played a huge role in who they chose to detain this way. Bail amounts climbed higher and higher, 
and more and more defendants couldn’t pay— so they stayed in jail. By the late 19th century, these circumstances led to the rise 
of commercial bail bond companies. They pay a defendant’s bail, in exchange
for a hefty fee the company keeps. Today, the median bail is $10,000— a prohibitively high price 
for almost half of Americans, and as many as nine out of ten defendants. If the defendant can’t pay, they may apply for a loan 
from a commercial bail bond company. It’s completely up to the company 
to decide whose bail they’ll pay. They choose defendants they think 
will pay them back, turning a profit of about
$2 billion each year. In fact, in the past 20 years, pretrial detention has been the main
driver of jail growth in America. Every year, hundreds of thousands 
of people who can’t afford bail or secure a loan
stay in jail until their case is resolved. This injustice disproportionately affects
Americans who are Black and Latino, for whom judges often set higher bail than for white people accused
of the same offenses. Unaffordable bail puts even innocent
defendants in an impossible position. Some end up pleading guilty to crimes 
they did not commit. For minor offenses, the prosecution 
may offer a deal that credits time already spent in jail toward 
the accused’s sentence if they plead guilty. Often, the time they’ve already spent in
jail is the total length of the sentence, and they can go home immediately—
but they leave with a criminal record. Defending their innocence, meanwhile, can mean staying in jail indefinitely
awaiting trial— and doesn’t guarantee 
an innocent verdict. Bail may not even be necessary
in the first place. Washington, D.C. largely abolished
cash bail in the 1990s. In 2017, the city released 94% 
of defendants without holding bail money, and 88% of them returned
to all their court dates. The nonprofit organization, 
The Bail Project, provides free bail assistance to thousands
of low-income people every year, removing the financial incentive
that bail is designed to create. The result? People come back 
to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, and those who miss their court dates 
tended to because of circumstances like child care,
work conflicts, or medical crises. Studies have also found that holding
people in jail before trial, often because they cannot
afford cash bail, actually increases the likelihood
of rearrests and reoffending. The damage of incarcerating people 
before their trials extends to entire communities
and can harm families for generations. People who are incarcerated 
can lose their livelihoods, homes, and access to essential services— all before they’ve been convicted 
of a crime. It’s also incredibly expensive: American taxpayers spend 
nearly $14 billion every year incarcerating people 
who are legally presumed innocent. This undermines the promise 
of equal justice under the law, regardless of race or wealth. The issues surrounding cash bail 
are symptomatic of societal problems, like structural racism and over-reliance
on incarceration, that need to be addressed. In the meantime, 
reformers like The Bail Project are working to help people trapped 
by cash bail and to create a more just and humane
pretrial system for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How is cash bail supposed to be determined?
Options: A. It should be based on the likelihood that you are guilty., B. It should be based on whether you have a criminal record., C. It should be based on the seriousness of the case., D. It should be based on how much money you can afford.
Correct Option: D

They are able to secure a loan from a commercial bail bond company, C. They stay in jail until their case is resolved, D. They are able to plead guilty to a lesser charge Correct Option: None

The defendant may lose their livelihood, home, and access to essential services, C. The defendant is able to plead guilty to a lesser charge, D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Since 2000, the annual number of people
convicted of crimes in the United States has stayed steady, but the average number
of people in jail each year has shot up. How can that be? The answer lies in the bail system— which isn’t doing 
what it was intended to do. The term "bail" refers to the release
of people awaiting trial on condition that they return 
to court to face charges. Countries around the world 
use many variations of bail, and some don’t use it at all. The U.S. bail system relies primarily 
on what’s called cash bail, which was supposed to work like this: When a person was accused of a crime, the judge would set 
a reasonable price for bail. The accused would pay this fee 
in order to be released from jail until the court reached 
a verdict on the case. Once the case ended, 
whether found guilty or innocent, they’d get the bail money back 
if they made all their court appearances. The rationale behind this system 
is that under U.S. law, people are presumed innocent
until proven guilty— so someone accused of a crime 
should not be imprisoned unless they’ve been convicted of a crime. But today, the bail system in the U.S. doesn’t honor the presumption
of innocence. Instead, it subverts peoples’ rights
and causes serious harm, particularly to people 
in low-income communities and communities of color. A key reason why is the cost of bail. In order for cash bail 
to work as intended, the price has to be affordable
for the accused. The cost of bail wasn’t meant to reflect
the likelihood of someone’s guilt— when bail is set, the court 
has not reviewed evidence. Under exceptional circumstances, 
such as charges of very serious crimes, judges could deny bail 
and jail the accused before their trial. Judges were supposed to exercise 
this power very rarely, and could come under scrutiny
for using it too often. Setting unaffordably high bail 
became a second path to denying people pretrial release. Judges' personal discretion 
and prejudices played a huge role in who they chose to detain this way. Bail amounts climbed higher and higher, 
and more and more defendants couldn’t pay— so they stayed in jail. By the late 19th century, these circumstances led to the rise 
of commercial bail bond companies. They pay a defendant’s bail, in exchange
for a hefty fee the company keeps. Today, the median bail is $10,000— a prohibitively high price 
for almost half of Americans, and as many as nine out of ten defendants. If the defendant can’t pay, they may apply for a loan 
from a commercial bail bond company. It’s completely up to the company 
to decide whose bail they’ll pay. They choose defendants they think 
will pay them back, turning a profit of about
$2 billion each year. In fact, in the past 20 years, pretrial detention has been the main
driver of jail growth in America. Every year, hundreds of thousands 
of people who can’t afford bail or secure a loan
stay in jail until their case is resolved. This injustice disproportionately affects
Americans who are Black and Latino, for whom judges often set higher bail than for white people accused
of the same offenses. Unaffordable bail puts even innocent
defendants in an impossible position. Some end up pleading guilty to crimes 
they did not commit. For minor offenses, the prosecution 
may offer a deal that credits time already spent in jail toward 
the accused’s sentence if they plead guilty. Often, the time they’ve already spent in
jail is the total length of the sentence, and they can go home immediately—
but they leave with a criminal record. Defending their innocence, meanwhile, can mean staying in jail indefinitely
awaiting trial— and doesn’t guarantee 
an innocent verdict. Bail may not even be necessary
in the first place. Washington, D.C. largely abolished
cash bail in the 1990s. In 2017, the city released 94% 
of defendants without holding bail money, and 88% of them returned
to all their court dates. The nonprofit organization, 
The Bail Project, provides free bail assistance to thousands
of low-income people every year, removing the financial incentive
that bail is designed to create. The result? People come back 
to 90% of their court dates without having any money on the line, and those who miss their court dates 
tended to because of circumstances like child care,
work conflicts, or medical crises. Studies have also found that holding
people in jail before trial, often because they cannot
afford cash bail, actually increases the likelihood
of rearrests and reoffending. The damage of incarcerating people 
before their trials extends to entire communities
and can harm families for generations. People who are incarcerated 
can lose their livelihoods, homes, and access to essential services— all before they’ve been convicted 
of a crime. It’s also incredibly expensive: American taxpayers spend 
nearly $14 billion every year incarcerating people 
who are legally presumed innocent. This undermines the promise 
of equal justice under the law, regardless of race or wealth. The issues surrounding cash bail 
are symptomatic of societal problems, like structural racism and over-reliance
on incarceration, that need to be addressed. In the meantime, 
reformers like The Bail Project are working to help people trapped 
by cash bail and to create a more just and humane
pretrial system for the future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why is cash bail necessary?
Options: A. To send a message that if you commit a crime there are consequences., B. To make sure people come back to court as required., C. There is no evidence that it’s necessary. To the contrary, data shows people come back to court to resolve their cases without a financial incentive., D. To keep the courts funded.
Correct Option: C

To fine people accused of crimes Correct Option: None

The cost of bail is not affordable for many people, C. The bail system is not being used often enough, D. The bail system is too lenient on people accused of crimes Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the median bail amount in the United States? Options: A. $1,000, B. $5,000, C. $10,000, D. $20,000 Correct Option: None

They are able to secure a loan from a commercial bail bond company, C. They stay in jail until their case is resolved, D. They are able to plead guilty to a lesser charge Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Emotional abuse can be
incredibly damaging, increasing a person’s chances 
of developing depression and anxiety sometimes for decades after the fact. Broadly speaking, emotional abuse involves
one person controlling another by undermining their sense of self-worth
and personal agency. But emotionally abusive behaviors can be
subtle and difficult to spot, both from within 
and outside the abusive relationship. That’s partly because emotional abuse
often exploits or creates power imbalances 
between individuals, especially in relationships
where safety, care, and trust are supposed to be guaranteed, like the relationship between
a caregiver and a child, healthcare provider and patient,
teacher and student, or intimate partners. It’s especially insidious because 
it often makes people doubt their perceptions 
of their own mistreatment. So let’s walk through some of the most
common signs of emotional abuse, to make these behaviors and patterns
easier to spot in real life. First, the content of someone’s words: criticism that’s out of proportion
to a situation, excessively harsh or personal,
or makes sweeping generalizations or baseless negative predictions 
for the future is a warning sign of emotional abuse. Statements like, “You always make
such stupid decisions,” “You never do anything right,” 
and “Nobody else will ever love you,” aren’t constructive; 
they’re never warranted, and someone’s use of them is a red flag. Second, tone and non-verbal cues: yelling, ignoring and showing contempt
through body language are all ways to degrade someone. Dismissive behaviors like eye rolling,
glaring, or refusal to make eye contact, along with refusing to speak to someone
or acknowledge their presence— sometimes called “the silent treatment”— can all feature in patterns 
of emotional abuse. These behaviors can painfully transform the meaning of spoken statements 
that might otherwise seem benign. Third, how someone reacts
to being told they’ve said or done something hurtful 
can give important insight: do they apologize sincerely 
and act differently in the future, or do they dismiss and minimize
the pain they’ve caused? It’s common for abusers to try 
to undermine their target’s perceptions of events— this is sometimes referred 
to as “gaslighting.” Following up demeaning,
humiliating, or threatening remarks with comments that dismiss
the impact of those remarks, like “I’m just trying to help you 
improve yourself— you should be grateful,” or “It’s really you that’s selfish 
and manipulative— you’re hurting me,” are examples of this behavior. Lastly, when someone directs any 
of these behaviors at you, take note of whether this is part 
of a pattern of behavior from them. A one-time incident of name-calling
or a demeaning insult might not be emotional abuse, while repetition over time can have 
a much more serious impact. Both frequency, how often these behaviors
occur in a given period of time, and duration, or how long they last, 
whether days or years, can contribute 
to the severity of the abuse. It’s also important to remember 
that abusers rarely engage in abusive behaviors 100% of the time— moments of kindness or calm 
don’t invalidate moments of abuse, but are actually part of the cycle
of emotional manipulation. So what can you do if you think you
or someone you care about is experiencing emotional abuse? Maintaining interpersonal ties with people
other than the abuser is crucial, as abusers often try to isolate 
their targets from others close to them. If you think you might be experiencing
emotional abuse, consider sharing your experiences
with a trusted friend or relative to get outside support. Or you can seek local or national
confidential advocacy centers that can provide helpful resources. And if you think someone you know
is being emotionally abused, check in with them. Let them know you’re thinking of them and that you're ready to listen
whenever they'd like to share. While emotional abusers may convince
people that they deserve to be mistreated, nobody does: everyone deserves
kindness and respect.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is the most fitting example of criticism that is a sweeping generalization?
Options: A. Comments such as, “You never do anything right.”, B. Statements such as, “Nobody else will ever love you.”, C. Refusal to make eye contact while refusing to acknowledge one’s presence., D. Remarks that undermine one’s perceptions of events.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is emotional abuse, and how can it affect a person? Options: A. Emotional abuse is physical harm that can lead to temporary emotional distress., B. Emotional abuse is controlling behavior that can increase a person's chances of developing depression and anxiety., C. Emotional abuse is a rare occurrence that has no long-term effects on a person's mental health., D. Emotional abuse is only found in romantic relationships and has no impact on a person's sense of self-worth. Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following relationships can be prone to emotional abuse due to power imbalances? Options: A. Only romantic relationships, B. Only friendships, C. Relationships between caregivers and children, healthcare providers and patients, teachers and students, or intimate partners, D. Only family relationships Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is a common sign of emotional abuse in the content of someone's words? Options: A. Criticism that is constructive and specific to a situation, B. Criticism that is out of proportion to a situation, excessively harsh or personal, C. Criticism that is only directed at a person's actions, not their character, D. Criticism that is always warranted and necessary Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which non-verbal cues can be indicative of emotional abuse? Options: A. Smiling, making eye contact, and active listening, B. Yelling, ignoring, and showing contempt through body language, C. Crossing one's arms, tapping one's foot, and raising one's voice, D. Giving compliments, offering support, and being empathetic Correct Option: None
Question 5: How might an abuser react when told they've said or done something hurtful? Options: A. They will always apologize sincerely and act differently in the future, B. They will dismiss and minimize the pain they've caused, C. They will become defensive and angry, but eventually take responsibility for their actions, D. They will ignore the situation and pretend it never happened Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is "gaslighting" in the context of emotional abuse? Options: A. A form of physical abuse that involves manipulation, B. A form of emotional manipulation where the abuser tries to undermine the target's perceptions of events, C. A form of verbal abuse that involves yelling and name-calling, D. A form of neglect that involves ignoring the target's needs Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is important to consider when evaluating whether someone's behavior is emotionally abusive? Options: A. Only the frequency of the behavior, B. Only the duration of the behavior, C. Both the frequency and duration of the behavior, D. Neither the frequency nor duration of the behavior Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why is it essential to maintain interpersonal ties with people other than the abuser? Options: A. So the abuser can be isolated and held accountable, B. So the target can be isolated and controlled, C. So the target can receive outside support and validation, D. So the abuser can receive outside support and validation Correct Option: None
Question 9: What can you do if you think someone you know is being emotionally abused? Options: A. Ignore the situation and hope it resolves itself, B. Confront the abuser and try to fix the situation, C. Check in with the person, let them know you're thinking of them, and offer to listen when they're ready to share, D. Tell the person to leave the relationship immediately Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is essential to remember about emotional abuse? Options: A. It's rare and only happens to certain people, B. It's always easy to spot and recognize, C. Nobody deserves to be mistreated, and everyone deserves kindness and respect, D. It's only found in romantic relationships Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, its content and options are the most similar. Question 3 asks about common signs of emotional abuse in the content of someone's words, and option B mentions criticism that is out of proportion to a situation, excessively harsh or personal. This is related to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about sweeping generalizations and provides an example of criticism that is a sweeping generalization ("You never do anything right"). 

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, and Question 3 is the closest approximation.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 2

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Emotional abuse can be
incredibly damaging, increasing a person’s chances 
of developing depression and anxiety sometimes for decades after the fact. Broadly speaking, emotional abuse involves
one person controlling another by undermining their sense of self-worth
and personal agency. But emotionally abusive behaviors can be
subtle and difficult to spot, both from within 
and outside the abusive relationship. That’s partly because emotional abuse
often exploits or creates power imbalances 
between individuals, especially in relationships
where safety, care, and trust are supposed to be guaranteed, like the relationship between
a caregiver and a child, healthcare provider and patient,
teacher and student, or intimate partners. It’s especially insidious because 
it often makes people doubt their perceptions 
of their own mistreatment. So let’s walk through some of the most
common signs of emotional abuse, to make these behaviors and patterns
easier to spot in real life. First, the content of someone’s words: criticism that’s out of proportion
to a situation, excessively harsh or personal,
or makes sweeping generalizations or baseless negative predictions 
for the future is a warning sign of emotional abuse. Statements like, “You always make
such stupid decisions,” “You never do anything right,” 
and “Nobody else will ever love you,” aren’t constructive; 
they’re never warranted, and someone’s use of them is a red flag. Second, tone and non-verbal cues: yelling, ignoring and showing contempt
through body language are all ways to degrade someone. Dismissive behaviors like eye rolling,
glaring, or refusal to make eye contact, along with refusing to speak to someone
or acknowledge their presence— sometimes called “the silent treatment”— can all feature in patterns 
of emotional abuse. These behaviors can painfully transform the meaning of spoken statements 
that might otherwise seem benign. Third, how someone reacts
to being told they’ve said or done something hurtful 
can give important insight: do they apologize sincerely 
and act differently in the future, or do they dismiss and minimize
the pain they’ve caused? It’s common for abusers to try 
to undermine their target’s perceptions of events— this is sometimes referred 
to as “gaslighting.” Following up demeaning,
humiliating, or threatening remarks with comments that dismiss
the impact of those remarks, like “I’m just trying to help you 
improve yourself— you should be grateful,” or “It’s really you that’s selfish 
and manipulative— you’re hurting me,” are examples of this behavior. Lastly, when someone directs any 
of these behaviors at you, take note of whether this is part 
of a pattern of behavior from them. A one-time incident of name-calling
or a demeaning insult might not be emotional abuse, while repetition over time can have 
a much more serious impact. Both frequency, how often these behaviors
occur in a given period of time, and duration, or how long they last, 
whether days or years, can contribute 
to the severity of the abuse. It’s also important to remember 
that abusers rarely engage in abusive behaviors 100% of the time— moments of kindness or calm 
don’t invalidate moments of abuse, but are actually part of the cycle
of emotional manipulation. So what can you do if you think you
or someone you care about is experiencing emotional abuse? Maintaining interpersonal ties with people
other than the abuser is crucial, as abusers often try to isolate 
their targets from others close to them. If you think you might be experiencing

with a trusted friend or relative to get outside support. Or you can seek local or national
confidential advocacy centers that can provide helpful resources. And if you think someone you know
is being emotionally abused, check in with them. Let them know you’re thinking of them and that you're ready to listen
whenever they'd like to share. While emotional abusers may convince
people that they deserve to be mistreated, nobody does: everyone deserves
kindness and respect.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is the most fitting example of a baseless negative prediction?
Options: A. Comments such as, “You never do anything right.”, B. Statements such as, “Nobody else will ever love you.”, C. Refusal to make eye contact while refusing to acknowledge one’s presence., D. Remarks that undermine one’s perceptions of events.
Correct Option: B

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

Although the question is not an exact match, the options and content are related to the ground truth MCQ. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Emotional abuse can be
incredibly damaging, increasing a person’s chances 
of developing depression and anxiety sometimes for decades after the fact. Broadly speaking, emotional abuse involves
one person controlling another by undermining their sense of self-worth
and personal agency. But emotionally abusive behaviors can be
subtle and difficult to spot, both from within 
and outside the abusive relationship. That’s partly because emotional abuse
often exploits or creates power imbalances 
between individuals, especially in relationships
where safety, care, and trust are supposed to be guaranteed, like the relationship between
a caregiver and a child, healthcare provider and patient,
teacher and student, or intimate partners. It’s especially insidious because 
it often makes people doubt their perceptions 
of their own mistreatment. So let’s walk through some of the most
common signs of emotional abuse, to make these behaviors and patterns
easier to spot in real life. First, the content of someone’s words: criticism that’s out of proportion
to a situation, excessively harsh or personal,
or makes sweeping generalizations or baseless negative predictions 
for the future is a warning sign of emotional abuse. Statements like, “You always make
such stupid decisions,” “You never do anything right,” 
and “Nobody else will ever love you,” aren’t constructive; 
they’re never warranted, and someone’s use of them is a red flag. Second, tone and non-verbal cues: yelling, ignoring and showing contempt
through body language are all ways to degrade someone. Dismissive behaviors like eye rolling,
glaring, or refusal to make eye contact, along with refusing to speak to someone
or acknowledge their presence— sometimes called “the silent treatment”— can all feature in patterns 
of emotional abuse. These behaviors can painfully transform the meaning of spoken statements 
that might otherwise seem benign. Third, how someone reacts
to being told they’ve said or done something hurtful 
can give important insight: do they apologize sincerely 
and act differently in the future, or do they dismiss and minimize
the pain they’ve caused? It’s common for abusers to try 
to undermine their target’s perceptions of events— this is sometimes referred 
to as “gaslighting.” Following up demeaning,
humiliating, or threatening remarks with comments that dismiss
the impact of those remarks, like “I’m just trying to help you 
improve yourself— you should be grateful,” or “It’s really you that’s selfish 
and manipulative— you’re hurting me,” are examples of this behavior. Lastly, when someone directs any 
of these behaviors at you, take note of whether this is part 
of a pattern of behavior from them. A one-time incident of name-calling
or a demeaning insult might not be emotional abuse, while repetition over time can have 
a much more serious impact. Both frequency, how often these behaviors
occur in a given period of time, and duration, or how long they last, 
whether days or years, can contribute 
to the severity of the abuse. It’s also important to remember 
that abusers rarely engage in abusive behaviors 100% of the time— moments of kindness or calm 
don’t invalidate moments of abuse, but are actually part of the cycle
of emotional manipulation. So what can you do if you think you
or someone you care about is experiencing emotional abuse? Maintaining interpersonal ties with people
other than the abuser is crucial, as abusers often try to isolate 
their targets from others close to them. If you think you might be experiencing
emotional abuse, consider sharing your experiences
with a trusted friend or relative to get outside support. Or you can seek local or national
confidential advocacy centers that can provide helpful resources. And if you think someone you know
is being emotionally abused, check in with them. Let them know you’re thinking of them and that you're ready to listen
whenever they'd like to share. While emotional abusers may convince
people that they deserve to be mistreated, nobody does: everyone deserves
kindness and respect.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is the most fitting example of dismissive behavior in the form of “silent treatment”?
Options: A. Comments such as, “You never do anything right.”, B. Statements such as, “Nobody else will ever love you.”, C. Refusal to make eye contact while refusing to acknowledge one’s presence., D. Remarks that undermine one’s perceptions of events.
Correct Option: C

Emotional abuse is controlling behavior that can increase a person's chances of developing depression and anxiety., C. Emotional abuse is a rare occurrence that has no long-term effects on a person's mental health., D. Emotional abuse is only found in romantic relationships and has no impact on a person's sense of self-worth. Correct Option: None

Criticism that is out of proportion to a situation, excessively harsh or personal, C. Criticism that is only directed at a person's actions, not their character, D. Criticism that is always warranted and necessary Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which non-verbal cues can be indicative of emotional abuse? Options: A. Smiling, making eye contact, and active listening, B. Yelling, ignoring, and showing contempt through body language, C. Crossing one's arms, tapping one's foot, and raising one's voice, D. Giving compliments, offering support, and being empathetic Correct Option: None
Question 5: How might an abuser react when told they've said or done something hurtful? Options: A. They will always apologize sincerely and act differently in the future, B. They will dismiss and minimize the pain they've caused, C. They will become defensive and angry, but eventually take responsibility for their actions, D. They will ignore the situation and pretend it never happened Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is "gaslighting" in the context of emotional abuse? Options: A. A form of physical abuse that involves manipulation, B. A form of emotional manipulation where the abuser tries to undermine the target's perceptions of events, C. A form of verbal abuse that involves yelling and name-calling, D. A form of neglect that involves ignoring the target's needs Correct Option: None

Both the frequency and duration of the behavior, D. Neither the frequency nor duration of the behavior Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why is it essential to maintain interpersonal ties with people other than the abuser? Options: A. So the abuser can be isolated and held accountable, B. So the target can be isolated and controlled, C. So the target can receive outside support and validation, D. So the abuser can receive outside support and validation Correct Option: None
Question 9: What can you do if you think someone you know is being emotionally abused? Options: A. Ignore the situation and hope it resolves itself, B. Confront the abuser and try to fix the situation, C. Check in with the person, let them know you're thinking of them, and offer to listen when they're ready to share, D. Tell the person to leave the relationship immediately Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is essential to remember about emotional abuse? Options: A. It's rare and only happens to certain people, B. It's always easy to spot and recognize, C. Nobody deserves to be mistreated, and everyone deserves kindness and respect, D. It's only found in romantic relationships Correct Option: None

The correct answer to the ground truth MCQ (C. Refusal to make eye contact while refusing to acknowledge one’s presence) is an example of a non-verbal cue, and option B of Question 4 (Yelling, ignoring, and showing contempt through body language) mentions ignoring, which is a part of the "silent treatment."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Emotional abuse can be
incredibly damaging, increasing a person’s chances 
of developing depression and anxiety sometimes for decades after the fact. Broadly speaking, emotional abuse involves
one person controlling another by undermining their sense of self-worth
and personal agency. But emotionally abusive behaviors can be
subtle and difficult to spot, both from within 
and outside the abusive relationship. That’s partly because emotional abuse
often exploits or creates power imbalances 
between individuals, especially in relationships
where safety, care, and trust are supposed to be guaranteed, like the relationship between
a caregiver and a child, healthcare provider and patient,
teacher and student, or intimate partners. It’s especially insidious because 
it often makes people doubt their perceptions 
of their own mistreatment. So let’s walk through some of the most
common signs of emotional abuse, to make these behaviors and patterns
easier to spot in real life. First, the content of someone’s words: criticism that’s out of proportion
to a situation, excessively harsh or personal,
or makes sweeping generalizations or baseless negative predictions 
for the future is a warning sign of emotional abuse. Statements like, “You always make
such stupid decisions,” “You never do anything right,” 
and “Nobody else will ever love you,” aren’t constructive; 
they’re never warranted, and someone’s use of them is a red flag. Second, tone and non-verbal cues: yelling, ignoring and showing contempt
through body language are all ways to degrade someone. Dismissive behaviors like eye rolling,
glaring, or refusal to make eye contact, along with refusing to speak to someone
or acknowledge their presence— sometimes called “the silent treatment”— can all feature in patterns 
of emotional abuse. These behaviors can painfully transform the meaning of spoken statements 
that might otherwise seem benign. Third, how someone reacts
to being told they’ve said or done something hurtful 
can give important insight: do they apologize sincerely 
and act differently in the future, or do they dismiss and minimize
the pain they’ve caused? It’s common for abusers to try 
to undermine their target’s perceptions of events— this is sometimes referred 
to as “gaslighting.” Following up demeaning,
humiliating, or threatening remarks with comments that dismiss
the impact of those remarks, like “I’m just trying to help you 
improve yourself— you should be grateful,” or “It’s really you that’s selfish 
and manipulative— you’re hurting me,” are examples of this behavior. Lastly, when someone directs any 
of these behaviors at you, take note of whether this is part 
of a pattern of behavior from them. A one-time incident of name-calling
or a demeaning insult might not be emotional abuse, while repetition over time can have 
a much more serious impact. Both frequency, how often these behaviors
occur in a given period of time, and duration, or how long they last, 
whether days or years, can contribute 
to the severity of the abuse. It’s also important to remember 
that abusers rarely engage in abusive behaviors 100% of the time— moments of kindness or calm 
don’t invalidate moments of abuse, but are actually part of the cycle
of emotional manipulation. So what can you do if you think you
or someone you care about is experiencing emotional abuse? Maintaining interpersonal ties with people
other than the abuser is crucial, as abusers often try to isolate 
their targets from others close to them. If you think you might be experiencing
emotional abuse, consider sharing your experiences
with a trusted friend or relative to get outside support. Or you can seek local or national
confidential advocacy centers that can provide helpful resources. And if you think someone you know
is being emotionally abused, check in with them. Let them know you’re thinking of them and that you're ready to listen
whenever they'd like to share. While emotional abusers may convince
people that they deserve to be mistreated, nobody does: everyone deserves
kindness and respect.

Correct Option: D

one person controlling another by undermining their sense of self-worth
and personal agency. But emotionally abusive behaviors can be

often exploits or creates power imbalances 
between individuals, especially in relationships

a caregiver and a child, healthcare provider and patient,

it often makes people doubt their perceptions 
of their own mistreatment. So let’s walk through some of the most

easier to spot in real life. First, the content of someone’s words: criticism that’s out of proportion
to a situation, excessively harsh or personal,
or makes sweeping generalizations or baseless negative predictions 
for the future is a warning sign of emotional abuse. Statements like, “You always make
such stupid decisions,” “You never do anything right,” 
and “Nobody else will ever love you,” aren’t constructive;

through body language are all ways to degrade someone. Dismissive behaviors like eye rolling,
glaring, or refusal to make eye contact, along with refusing to speak to someone

can give important insight: do they apologize sincerely 
and act differently in the future, or do they dismiss and minimize

to as “gaslighting.” Following up demeaning,

of a pattern of behavior from them. A one-time incident of name-calling
or a demeaning insult might not be emotional abuse, while repetition over time can have 
a much more serious impact. Both frequency, how often these behaviors
occur in a given period of time, and duration, or how long they last, 
whether days or years, can contribute 
to the severity of the abuse. It’s also important to remember

don’t invalidate moments of abuse, but are actually part of the cycle

other than the abuser is crucial, as abusers often try to isolate 
their targets from others close to them. If you think you might be experiencing

with a trusted friend or relative to get outside support. Or you can seek local or national

whenever they'd like to share. While emotional abusers may convince
